A **camel** is an [even-toed ungulate](/wiki/Even-toed_ungulate "Even-toed
ungulate") in the genus _**Camelus**_ that bears distinctive fatty deposits
known as "humps" on its back. Camels have long been domesticated and, as
[livestock](/wiki/Livestock "Livestock"), they provide food
([milk](/wiki/Camel_milk "Camel milk") and meat) and textiles (fiber and felt
from [hair](/wiki/Camel_hair "Camel hair")). As [working
animals](/wiki/Working_animal "Working animal"), camels—who are uniquely
suited to their desert habitats—are a vital means of transport for passengers
and cargo. There are three surviving species of camel. The one-humped
[dromedary](/wiki/Dromedary "Dromedary") makes up 94% of the world's camel
population, and the two-humped [Bactrian camel](/wiki/Bactrian_camel "Bactrian
camel") makes up the remainder. The [Wild Bactrian
camel](/wiki/Wild_Bactrian_camel "Wild Bactrian camel") is a separate species
and is now critically endangered.

The word _camel_ is derived via [Latin](/wiki/Latin_language "Latin
language"): _camelus_ and [Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language"):
κάμηλος (_kamēlos_) from Hebrew or Phoenician: _gāmāl_.[3][4] Used informally,
"camel" (or, more correctly, "camelid") refers to any of the seven members of
the family Camelidae: the dromedary, the Bactrian, and the wild Bactrian (the
true camels) plus the [llama](/wiki/Llama "Llama"), the [alpaca](/wiki/Alpaca
"Alpaca"), the [guanaco](/wiki/Guanaco "Guanaco"), and the
[vicuña](/wiki/Vicu%C3%B1a "Vicuña")[5] (the "New World" camelids).

The dromedary (_C. dromedarius_), also known as the _Arabian camel_ , inhabits
the [Middle East](/wiki/Middle_East "Middle East") and the [Horn of
Africa](/wiki/Horn_of_Africa "Horn of Africa"), while the Bactrian (_C.
bactrianus_) inhabits [Central Asia](/wiki/Central_Asia "Central Asia"),
including the historical region of [Bactria](/wiki/Bactria "Bactria"). The
critically endangered wild Bactrian (_C. ferus_) is found only in remote areas
of [northwest China](/wiki/Northwest_China "Northwest China") and
[Mongolia](/wiki/Mongolia "Mongolia"). An extinct species of camel[6] in the
separate genus _**[Camelops](/wiki/Camelops "Camelops")**_ , known as _C.
hesternus_ ,[7] lived in western [North America](/wiki/North_America "North
America") before humans entered the continent at the end of the
[Pleistocene](/wiki/Pleistocene "Pleistocene").

## Biology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Camel&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Biology")]

The average [life expectancy](/wiki/Life_expectancy "Life expectancy") of a
camel is 40 to 50 years.[8][9][_[not in citation
given](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")_] A full-grown
adult camel stands 1.85 m (6 ft 1 in) at the shoulder and 2.15 m (7 ft 1 in)
at the hump.[10] Camels can run at up to 65 km/h (40 mph) in short bursts and
sustain speeds of up to 40 km/h (25 mph).[11] Bactrian camels weigh 300 to
1,000 kg (660 to 2,200 lb) and dromedaries 300 to 600 kg (660 to 1,320 lb).
The widening toes on a camel's hoof provide supplemental grip for varying soil
sediments.[12]

The male dromedary camel has an organ called a [dulla](/wiki/Dulla_\(organ\)
"Dulla \(organ\)") in its throat, a large, inflatable sac he extrudes from his
mouth when in [rut](/wiki/Rut_\(mammalian_reproduction\) "Rut \(mammalian
reproduction\)") to assert dominance and attract females. It resembles a long,
swollen, pink tongue hanging out of the side of its mouth.[13] Camels mate by
having both male and female sitting on the ground, with the male mounting from
behind.[14] The male usually [ejaculates](/wiki/Ejaculates "Ejaculates") three
or four times within a single mating session.[15] Camelids are the only
ungulates to mate in a sitting position.[16]

### Ecological and behavioral
adaptations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Camel&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Ecological and behavioral adaptations")]

Camels do not directly store water in their humps as was once commonly
believed. The humps are reservoirs of fatty tissue: concentrating [body
fat](/wiki/Adipose_tissue "Adipose tissue") in their humps minimizes the
insulating effect fat would have if distributed over the rest of their bodies,
helping camels survive in hot climates.[17][18] When this tissue is
metabolized, it yields more than one gram of water for every gram of fat
processed. This [fat metabolization](/wiki/Lipolysis "Lipolysis"), while
releasing energy, causes water to evaporate from the lungs during
[respiration](/wiki/Breathing "Breathing") (as oxygen is required for the
metabolic process): overall, there is a net decrease in water.[19][20]

[![A portrait of a camel with a visibly thick
mane](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Camel_portrait.jpg/170px-
Camel_portrait.jpg)](/wiki/File:Camel_portrait.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Camel_portrait.jpg "Enlarge")

A camel's thick coat is one of its many adaptations that aid it in desert-like
conditions.

[![A leashed pack
camel](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Eylcamel.jpg/220px-
Eylcamel.jpg)](/wiki/File:Eylcamel.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Eylcamel.jpg "Enlarge")

[Somalia](/wiki/Wildlife_of_Somalia "Wildlife of Somalia") has the world's
largest population of camels.[21]

Camels have a series of physiological adaptations that allow them to withstand
long periods of time without any external source of water.[18] The dromedary
camel can drink as seldom as once every 10 days even under very hot
conditions, and can lose up to 30% of its body mass due to dehydration.[22]
Unlike other mammals, camels' [red blood cells](/wiki/Red_blood_cell "Red
blood cell") are oval rather than circular in shape. This facilitates the flow
of red blood cells during dehydration[23] and makes them better at
withstanding high [osmotic](/wiki/Osmosis "Osmosis") variation without
rupturing when drinking large amounts of water: a 600 kg (1,300 lb) camel can
drink 200 L (53 US gal) of water in three minutes.[24][25]

Camels are able to withstand changes in [body
temperature](/wiki/Body_temperature "Body temperature") and water consumption
that would kill most other animals. Their temperature ranges from 34 °C (93
°F) at dawn and steadily increases to 40 °C (104 °F) by sunset, before they
cool off at night again.[18] In general, to compare between camels and the
other livestock, camels lose only 1.3 liters of fluid intake every day while
the other livestock lose 20 to 40 liters per day (Breulmann, et al., 2007)[26]
Maintaining the brain temperature within certain limits is critical for
animals; to assist this, camels have a [rete mirabile](/wiki/Rete_mirabile
"Rete mirabile"), a complex of arteries and veins lying very close to each
other which utilizes countercurrent blood flow to cool blood flowing to the
brain.[27] Camels rarely sweat, even when ambient temperatures reach 49 °C
(120 °F).[8] Any sweat that does occur evaporates at the skin level rather
than at the surface of their coat; the [heat of
vaporization](/wiki/Heat_of_vaporization "Heat of vaporization") therefore
comes from body heat rather than ambient heat. Camels can withstand losing 25%
of their body weight to sweating, whereas most other mammals can withstand
only about 12–14% dehydration before [cardiac
failure](/wiki/Congestive_heart_failure "Congestive heart failure") results
from circulatory disturbance.[25]

When the camel exhales, [water vapor](/wiki/Water_vapor "Water vapor") becomes
trapped in their [nostrils](/wiki/Nostrils "Nostrils") and is reabsorbed into
the body as a means to conserve water.[28] Camels eating green herbage can
ingest sufficient moisture in milder conditions to maintain their bodies'
hydrated state without the need for drinking.[29]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Camels_in_Dubai_2.jpg/220px-
Camels_in_Dubai_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Camels_in_Dubai_2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Camels_in_Dubai_2.jpg "Enlarge")

Domesticated camel calves lying in sternal recumbency, a position that aids
heat loss

The camels' thick coats insulate them from the intense heat radiated from
desert sand; a shorn camel must sweat 50% more to avoid overheating.[30]
During the summer the coat becomes lighter in color, reflecting light as well
as helping avoid sunburn.[25] The camel's long legs help by keeping its body
farther from the ground, which can heat up to 70 °C (158 °F).[31][32]
Dromedaries have a pad of thick tissue over the [sternum](/wiki/Sternum
"Sternum") called the _pedestal_. When the animal lies down in a sternal
recumbent position, the pedestal raises the body from the hot surface and
allows cooling air to pass under the body.[27]

Camels' mouths have a thick leathery lining, allowing them to chew thorny
desert plants. Long eyelashes and ear hairs, together with nostrils that can
close, form a barrier against sand. If sand gets lodged in their eyes, they
can dislodge it using their [transparent third
eyelid](/wiki/Nicitating_membrane "Nicitating membrane"). The camels' gait and
widened feet help them move without sinking into the sand.[31][33][34]

The [kidneys](/wiki/Kidney "Kidney") and [intestines](/wiki/Intestines
"Intestines") of a camel are very efficient at reabsorbing water. Camels'
kidneys have a 1:4 [cortex](/wiki/Renal_cortex "Renal cortex") to [medulla
ratio](/wiki/Renal_medulla "Renal medulla").[35] Thus medullary part of
camel's kidneys occupy twice as much area as a cow's kidney. Secondly, [renal
corpuscles](/wiki/Renal_corpuscles "Renal corpuscles") have a smaller
diameter, which reduces surface area for filtration. These two major
anatomical characteristics enable camel to conserve water and limit the volume
of urine in extreme desert conditions.[36] Camel urine comes out as a thick
syrup, and camel feces are so dry that they do not require drying when the
[Bedouins](/wiki/Bedouins "Bedouins") use them to fuel fires.[37][38][39][40]
The camels are able to live in difficult conditions without drinking water due
to their ability to produce small and dry droppings as well as they use the
water to maintain their body’s temperature to fit with the region surrounding
them (Breulmann, et al., 2007).[41]

The camel [immune system](/wiki/Immune_system "Immune system") differs from
those of other mammals. Normally, the Y-shaped [antibody](/wiki/Antibody
"Antibody") molecules consist of two heavy (or long) chains along the length
of the Y, and two light (or short) chains at each tip of the Y. Camels, in
addition to these, also have antibodies made of only two heavy chains, a trait
that makes them smaller and more durable. These "heavy-chain-only" antibodies,
discovered in 1993, are thought to have developed 50 million years ago, after
camelids split from ruminants and pigs.[42]

### Genetics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Camel&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Genetics")]

[![Three camels in a line: a person rides on the leading
camel.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Camels_at_Giza.JPG/220px-
Camels_at_Giza.JPG)](/wiki/File:Camels_at_Giza.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Camels_at_Giza.JPG "Enlarge")

Caravan of dromedaries  
_[Pyramids of Giza, Egypt](/wiki/Giza_pyramid_complex "Giza pyramid complex")_

The [karyotypes](/wiki/Karyotype "Karyotype") of different camelid species
have been studied earlier by many groups,[43][44][45][46][47][48] but no
agreement on chromosome nomenclature of camelids has been reached. A 2007
study [flow sorted](/wiki/Flow_sorting "Flow sorting") camel chromosomes,
building on the fact that camels have 37 pairs of chromosomes (2n=74), and
found that the karyotime consisted of one
[metacentric](/wiki/Centromere#Metacentric "Centromere"), three
submetacentric, and 32 acrocentric autosomes. The [Y](/wiki/Y_chromosome "Y
chromosome") is a small metacentric chromosome, while the
[X](/wiki/X_chromosome "X chromosome") is a large metacentric chromosome.[49]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Camel_skull.jpg/220px-
Camel_skull.jpg)](/wiki/File:Camel_skull.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Camel_skull.jpg "Enlarge")

Skull of an F1 hybrid camel  
_[Museum of Osteology](/wiki/Museum_of_Osteology "Museum of Osteology"),
Oklahoma_

The [hybrid camel](/wiki/Hybrid_camel "Hybrid camel"), a hybrid between
Bactrian and dromedary camels, has one hump, though it has an indentation 4–12
cm (1.6–4.7 in) deep that divides the front from the back. The hybrid is 2.15
m (7 ft 1 in) at the shoulder and 2.32 m (7 ft 7 in) tall at the hump. It
weighs an average of 650 kg (1,430 lb) and can carry around 400 to 450 kg (880
to 990 lb), which is more than either the dromedary or Bactrian can.[50]

According to molecular data, the New World and Old World camelids diverged
about 11 million years ago.[51] In spite of this, these species can hybridize
and produce viable offspring.[52] The [cama](/wiki/Cama_\(animal\) "Cama
\(animal\)") is a camel-lama hybrid bred by scientists to see how closely
related the parent species are.[53] Scientists [collected
semen](/wiki/Collected_semen "Collected semen") from a camel via an artificial
vagina and inseminated a llama after stimulating ovulation with
[gonadotrophin](/wiki/Gonadotrophin "Gonadotrophin") injections.[54] The cama
is halfway in size between a camel and a llama and lacks a hump. It has ears
intermediate between those of camels and llamas, longer legs than the llama,
and partially [cloven hooves](/wiki/Cloven-hoof "Cloven-hoof").[55][56] Like
the [mule](/wiki/Mule "Mule"), camas are sterile, despite both parents having
the same number of chromosomes.[54] The wild Bactrian camel (_C. ferus_)
separated from the domestic Bactrian camel (_C. bactrianus_) about 1 million
years ago.[57][58]

### Evolution[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Camel&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Evolution")]

[![A drawing of two early
camels](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Stenomylus.jpg/220px-
Stenomylus.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stenomylus.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Stenomylus.jpg "Enlarge")

Antelope-like ancient camel, _[Stenomylus](/wiki/Stenomylus "Stenomylus")_

The earliest known camel, called _[Protylopus](/wiki/Protylopus "Protylopus")_
, lived in North America 40 to 50 million years ago (during the
[Eocene](/wiki/Eocene "Eocene")).[15] It was about the size of a rabbit and
lived in the open woodlands of what is now [South Dakota](/wiki/South_Dakota
"South Dakota").[59][60] By 35 million years ago, the
_[Poebrotherium](/wiki/Poebrotherium "Poebrotherium")_ was the size of a goat
and had many more traits similar to camels and llamas.[61][62] The hoofed
_[Stenomylus](/wiki/Stenomylus "Stenomylus")_ , which walked on the tips of
its toes, also existed around this time, and the long-necked
_[Aepycamelus](/wiki/Aepycamelus "Aepycamelus")_ evolved in the
[Miocene](/wiki/Miocene "Miocene").[63]

The direct ancestor of all modern camels, _[Procamelus](/wiki/Procamelus
"Procamelus")_ , existed in the upper Miocene and lower Pliocene.[64] Around
3–5 million years ago, the North American Camelidae spread to South America as
part of the [Great American Interchange](/wiki/Great_American_Interchange
"Great American Interchange") via the newly formed [Isthmus of
Panama](/wiki/Isthmus_of_Panama "Isthmus of Panama"), where they gave rise to
[guanacos](/wiki/Guanacos "Guanacos") and related animals, and to Asia via the
[Bering land bridge](/wiki/Beringia "Beringia").[15][59][60] Surprising finds
of fossil _[Paracamelus](/wiki/Paracamelus "Paracamelus")_ on [Ellesmere
Island](/wiki/Ellesmere_Island "Ellesmere Island") beginning in 2006 in the
high Canadian Arctic indicate the dromedary is descended from a larger, boreal
browser whose hump may have evolved as an adaptation in a cold
climate.[65][66] This creature is estimated to have stood around nine feet
tall.[67]

The last camel native to North America was _[Camelops
hesternus](/wiki/Camelops_hesternus "Camelops hesternus")_ , which vanished
along with [horses](/wiki/Horse "Horse"), [short-faced bears](/wiki/Short-
faced_bear "Short-faced bear"), [mammoths](/wiki/Mammoth "Mammoth") and
[mastodons](/wiki/Mastodon "Mastodon"), [ground sloths](/wiki/Ground_sloth
"Ground sloth"), [sabertooth cats](/wiki/Sabertooth_cat "Sabertooth cat"), and
many other megafauna, coinciding with the migration of humans from
Asia.[68][69]

"Joseph Sells Grain"  
_by[Bartholomeus Breenbergh](/wiki/Bartholomeus_Breenbergh "Bartholomeus
Breenbergh") (1655)_  
[Note camel with rider, at left]

Like the horse, before their extinction in their native land, camels spread
across the Bering land bridge, moving the opposite direction from the Asian
immigration to America, to survive in the Old World and eventually be
domesticated and spread globally by humans. Most camels surviving today are
domesticated.[40][70] Along with many other megafauna in North America, the
original wild camels were wiped out during the spread of [Native
Americans](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas "Indigenous peoples of the
Americas") from Asia into North America, 12,000 to 10,000 years ago.[68][69]
Although feral populations exist in Australia, India and Kazakhstan, the only
wild camels left are the [wild Bactrian camels](/wiki/Wild_Bactrian_camel
"Wild Bactrian camel") of the [Gobi Desert](/wiki/Gobi_Desert "Gobi
Desert").[9]

Dromedaries may have first been domesticated by humans in Somalia and southern
Arabia, around 3,000 BC, the Bactrian in [central Asia](/wiki/Central_Asia
"Central Asia") around 2,500 BC,[15][71][72][73] as at Shar-i Sokhta (also
known as the Burnt City), [Iran](/wiki/Iran "Iran").[74]

Discussions concerning camel domestication in [Mesopotamia](/wiki/Mesopotamia
"Mesopotamia") are often related to mentions of camels in the [Hebrew
Bible](/wiki/Hebrew_Bible "Hebrew Bible"). The _International Standard Bible
Encyclopedia: E-J_ for instance mentions that "In accord with patriarchal
traditions, cylinder seals from Middle Bronze Age Mesopotamia showed riders
seated upon camels."[75][76]

Martin Heide's 2010 work on the domestication of the camel tentatively
concludes that the bactrian camel was domesticated by at least the middle of
the third millennium somewhere east of the [Zagros
Mountains](/wiki/Zagros_Mountains "Zagros Mountains"), then moving into
Mesopotamia, and suggests that mentions of camels "in the patriarchal
narratives may refer, at least in some places, to the Bactrian camel." while
noting that the camel is not mentioned in relationship to
[Canaan](/wiki/Canaan "Canaan").[77]

Recent excavations in the [Timna Valley](/wiki/Timna_Valley "Timna Valley") by
Lidar Sapir-Hen and Erez Ben-Yosef discovered what may be the earliest
domestic camel bones found in Israel or even outside the [Arabian
Peninsula](/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula "Arabian Peninsula"), dating to around 930
BC. This garnered considerable media coverage as it was described as evidence
that the stories of [Abraham](/wiki/Abraham "Abraham"), [Jacob](/wiki/Jacob
"Jacob"), [Esau](/wiki/Esau "Esau"), and [Joseph](/wiki/Joseph_\(Genesis\)
"Joseph \(Genesis\)") were written after this time.[78][79]

The existence of camels in Mesopotamia but not in Israel is not a new idea.
The historian [Richard Bulliet](/wiki/Richard_Bulliet "Richard Bulliet") did
not think that the occasional mention of camels meant that the domestic camels
were common in the Holy Land at that time.[80] The archaeologist [William F.
Albright](/wiki/William_F._Albright "William F. Albright") writing even
earlier saw camels in the Bible as an [anachronism](/wiki/Anachronism
"Anachronism").[81]

The official report by Sapir-Hen and Ben-Joseph notes that "The introduction
of the dromedary camel (Camelus dromedarius) as a pack animal to the [southern
Levant](/wiki/Southern_Levant "Southern Levant") ... substantially facilitated
trade across the vast deserts of Arabia, promoting both economic and social
change (e.g., Kohler 1984; Borowski 1998: 112–116; Jasmin 2005). This ... has
generated extensive discussion regarding the date of the earliest domestic
camel in the southern Levant (and beyond) (e.g., Albright 1949: 207; Epstein
1971: 558–584; Bulliet 1975; Zarins 1989; Köhler-Rollefson 1993; Uerpmann and
Uerpmann 2002; Jasmin 2005; 2006; Heide 2010; Rosen and Saidel 2010; Grigson
2012). Most scholars today agree that the dromedary was exploited as a pack
animal sometime in the early [Iron Age](/wiki/Iron_Age "Iron Age") (not before
the 12th century [BC])" and concludes that "Current data from copper smelting
sites of the [Aravah Valley](/wiki/Arabah "Arabah") enable us to pinpoint the
introduction of domestic camels to the southern Levant more precisely based on
stratigraphic contexts associated with an extensive suite of [radiocarbon
dates](/wiki/Radiocarbon_dating "Radiocarbon dating"). The data indicate that
this event occurred not earlier than the last third of the 10th century [BC]
and most probably during this time. The coincidence of this event with a major
reorganization of the copper industry of the region—attributed to the results
of the campaign of Pharaoh [Shoshenq I](/wiki/Shoshenq_I "Shoshenq I")—raises
the possibility that the two were connected, and that camels were introduced
as part of the efforts to improve efficiency by facilitating trade."[79]

### Textiles[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Camel&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Textiles")]

Main article: [Camel hair](/wiki/Camel_hair "Camel hair")

Desert tribes and Mongolian nomads use camel hair for tents,
[yurts](/wiki/Yurt "Yurt"), clothing, bedding and accessories. Camels have
outer guard hairs and soft inner down, and the fibers are sorted by color and
age of the animal. The guard hairs can be felted for use as waterproof coats
for the herdsmen, while the softer hair is used for premium goods.[82] The
fiber can be spun for use in weaving or made into yarns for hand knitting or
crochet. Pure camel hair is recorded as being used for western garments from
the 17th century onwards, and from the 19th century a mixture of wool and
camel hair was used.[83]

### Military uses[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Camel&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Military uses")]

Main article: [Camel cavalry](/wiki/Camel_cavalry "Camel cavalry")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/BSF-
Republic_day.jpeg/220px-BSF-Republic_day.jpeg)](/wiki/File:BSF-
Republic_day.jpeg)

[](/wiki/File:BSF-Republic_day.jpeg "Enlarge")

A special [BSF](/wiki/Border_Security_Force "Border Security Force") camel
contingent  
_[Republic Day Parade](/wiki/Republic_Day_\(India\) "Republic Day \(India\)"),
New Delhi (2004)_

[![A painting of soldiers on
camels](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Camel_corps_at_Magdhaba.jpg/220px-
Camel_corps_at_Magdhaba.jpg)](/wiki/File:Camel_corps_at_Magdhaba.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Camel_corps_at_Magdhaba.jpg "Enlarge")

"[Camel Corps](/wiki/Bikaner_Camel_Corps "Bikaner Camel Corps") at
[Magdhaba](/wiki/Battle_of_Magdhaba "Battle of Magdhaba")"  
Egypt, 23 December 1916  
_by[Harold Septimus Power](/wiki/Harold_Septimus_Power "Harold Septimus
Power") (1925)_

By at least 1200 BC, the first camel saddles had appeared, and [Bactrian
camels](/wiki/Bactrian_camels "Bactrian camels") could be ridden. The first
saddle was positioned to the back of the camel, and control of the Bactrian
camel was exercised by means of a stick. However, between 500–100 BC, Bactrian
camels attained military use. New saddles, which were inflexible and bent,
were put over the humps and divided the rider's weight over the animal. In the
seventh century BC, the military Arabian saddle appeared, which again improved
the saddle design slightly.[84]

[Camel cavalries](/wiki/Camel_cavalry "Camel cavalry") have been used in wars
throughout Africa, the Middle East, and into modern-day [Border Security
Force](/wiki/Border_Security_Force "Border Security Force") of
[India](/wiki/India "India") (though as of July 2012, the BSF has planned the
replacement of camels with [ATVs](/wiki/All-terrain_vehicle "All-terrain
vehicle")). The first use of camel cavalries was in the [Battle of
Qarqar](/wiki/Battle_of_Qarqar "Battle of Qarqar") in 853 BC.[85][86][87]
Armies have also used camels as freight animals instead of horses and
mules.[88][89]

In the [East Roman Empire](/wiki/East_Roman_Empire "East Roman Empire"), the
Romans used [auxiliary](/wiki/Auxiliaries_\(Roman_military\) "Auxiliaries
\(Roman military\)") forces known as _[dromedarii](/wiki/Dromedarii
"Dromedarii")_ , whom they recruited in desert provinces.[90][91] The camels
were used mostly in combat because of their ability to scare off horses at
close ranges (horses are afraid of the camels' scent),[16] a quality famously
employed by the [Achaemenid](/wiki/Achaemenid "Achaemenid") Persians when
fighting [Lydia](/wiki/Lydia "Lydia") in the [Battle of
Thymbra](/wiki/Battle_of_Thymbra "Battle of Thymbra").[50][92][93]

#### 19th and 20th
centuries[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Camel&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section:
19th and 20th centuries")]

[![A photo of Bulgarian military transport camels in
1912](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Camels_on_the_way_to_Catalca%2C_1912.jpg/220px-
Camels_on_the_way_to_Catalca%2C_1912.jpg)](/wiki/File:Camels_on_the_way_to_Catalca,_1912.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Camels_on_the_way_to_Catalca,_1912.jpg "Enlarge")

A [camel caravan](/wiki/Camel_train "Camel train") of the [Bulgarian
military](/wiki/Military_of_Bulgaria "Military of Bulgaria") during the [First
Balkan War](/wiki/First_Balkan_War "First Balkan War"), 1912

  * The [United States Army](/wiki/United_States_Army "United States Army") established the [U.S. Camel Corps](/wiki/U.S._Camel_Corps "U.S. Camel Corps"), which was stationed in [California](/wiki/California "California") in the late 19th century.[16] One may still see stables at the [Benicia Arsenal](/wiki/Benicia_Arsenal "Benicia Arsenal") in [Benicia, California](/wiki/Benicia,_California "Benicia, California"), where they nowadays serve as the Benicia Historical Museum.[94] Though the experimental use of camels was seen as a success ([John B. Floyd](/wiki/John_B._Floyd "John B. Floyd"), [Secretary of War](/wiki/Secretary_of_War "Secretary of War") in 1858, recommended that funds be allocated towards obtaining a thousand more camels), the outbreak of the [American Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American Civil War") saw the end of the Camel Corps: Texas became part of the Confederacy, and most of the camels were left to wander away into the desert.[89]
  * France created a _[méhariste](/wiki/M%C3%A9hariste "Méhariste")_ camel corps in 1912 as part of the Armée d'Afrique in the Sahara[95] in order to exercise greater control over the camel-riding [Tuareg](/wiki/Tuareg "Tuareg") and Arab insurgents, as previous efforts to defeat them on foot had failed.[96] The [Free French Camel Corps](/wiki/Free_French_Camel_Corps "Free French Camel Corps") fought during [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") and camel-mounted units remained in service until the end of French rule over Algeria in 1962.[97]
  * In 1916, the British created the [Imperial Camel Corps](/wiki/Imperial_Camel_Corps "Imperial Camel Corps"). It was originally used to fight the [Senussi](/wiki/Senussi "Senussi"), but was later used in the [Sinai and Palestine Campaign](/wiki/Sinai_and_Palestine_Campaign "Sinai and Palestine Campaign") in [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"). The Imperial Camel Corps comprised infantrymen mounted on camels for movement across desert, though they dismounted at battle sites and fought on foot. After July 1918, the Corps began to become run down, receiving no new reinforcements, and was formally disbanded in 1919.[98]
  * In World War I, the British Army also created the [Egyptian Camel Transport Corps](/wiki/Egyptian_Camel_Transport_Corps "Egyptian Camel Transport Corps"), which consisted of a group of Egyptian camel drivers and their camels. The Corps supported British war operations in [Sinai](/wiki/Sinai_Peninsula "Sinai Peninsula"), Palestine, and Syria by transporting supplies to the troops.[99][100][101]
  * The [Somaliland Camel Corps](/wiki/Somaliland_Camel_Corps "Somaliland Camel Corps") was created by colonial authorities in [British Somaliland](/wiki/British_Somaliland "British Somaliland") in 1912; it was disbanded in 1944.[102]
  * Bactrian camels were used by Romanian forces during [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") in the Caucasian region.[103]
  * The [Bikaner Camel Corps](/wiki/Bikaner_Camel_Corps "Bikaner Camel Corps") of [British India](/wiki/British_India "British India") fought alongside the [British Indian Army](/wiki/British_Indian_Army "British Indian Army") in World Wars I and II.[104]
  * The _[Tropas Nómadas](/wiki/Tropas_N%C3%B3madas "Tropas Nómadas")_ (Nomad Troops) were an auxiliary regiment of [Sahrawi](/wiki/Sahrawi_people "Sahrawi people") tribesmen serving in the colonial army in Spanish Sahara (today [Western Sahara](/wiki/Western_Sahara "Western Sahara")). Operational from the 1930s until the end of the Spanish presence in the territory in 1975, the _Tropas Nómadas_ were equipped with small arms and led by Spanish officers. The unit guarded outposts and sometimes conducted patrols on camelback.[105][106]

### Food uses[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Camel&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Food uses")]

#### Dairy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Camel&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Dairy")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Khan_al-
Lajjun.jpg/220px-Khan_al-Lajjun.jpg)](/wiki/File:Khan_al-Lajjun.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Khan_al-Lajjun.jpg "Enlarge")

Camels at the Khan and old bridge, [Lajjun](/wiki/Lajjun "Lajjun"),
[Palestine](/wiki/Palestine_\(region\) "Palestine \(region\)") (now in
[Israel](/wiki/Israel "Israel")) - 1870's drawing

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Camelcalf-
feeding.jpg/220px-Camelcalf-feeding.jpg)](/wiki/File:Camelcalf-feeding.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Camelcalf-feeding.jpg "Enlarge")

A camel calf nursing on  
[camel milk](/wiki/Camel_milk "Camel milk")

Main article: [Camel milk](/wiki/Camel_milk "Camel milk")

Camel milk is a [staple food](/wiki/Staple_food "Staple food") of desert nomad
tribes and is sometimes considered a meal itself; a nomad can live on only
camel milk for almost a month.[16][37][107][108] Camel milk is rich in
vitamins, minerals, proteins, and immunoglobulins;[109] compared to cow's
milk, it is lower in fat and lactose,[110] and higher in potassium, iron, and
vitamin C.[10] Bedouins believe the curative powers of camel milk are enhanced
if the camel's diet consists of certain desert plants.[16][111] Camel milk can
readily be made into a drinkable [yogurt](/wiki/Yogurt "Yogurt"), as well as
butter or cheese, though the yields for cheese tend to be low.[16][110]

Camel milk cannot be made into [butter](/wiki/Butter "Butter") by the
traditional churning method. It can be made if it is soured first, churned,
and a [clarifying agent](/wiki/Clarifying_agent "Clarifying agent") is then
added.[16] Until recently, camel milk could not be made into [camel
cheese](/wiki/Camel_milk "Camel milk") because [rennet](/wiki/Rennet "Rennet")
was unable to coagulate the milk proteins to allow the collection of
[curds](/wiki/Curd "Curd").[112] Developing less wasteful uses of the milk,
the [FAO](/wiki/Food_and_Agriculture_Organization "Food and Agriculture
Organization") commissioned Professor J.P. Ramet of the [École Nationale
Supérieure d'Agronomie et des Industries
Alimentaires](/wiki/%C3%89cole_Nationale_Sup%C3%A9rieure_d%27Agronomie_et_des_Industries_Alimentaires
"École Nationale Supérieure d'Agronomie et des Industries Alimentaires"), who
was able to produce curdling by the addition of [calcium
phosphate](/wiki/Calcium_phosphate "Calcium phosphate") and vegetable
rennet.[110] The cheese produced from this process has low levels of
cholesterol and is easy to digest, even for the lactose intolerant.[113][114]
The sale of camel cheese is limited owing to the small output of the few
dairies producing camel cheese and the absence of camel cheese in local (West
African) markets.[110] Cheese imports from countries that traditionally breed
camels are difficult to obtain due to restrictions on dairy imports from these
regions.[115]

Additionally, camel milk has been made into [ice cream](/wiki/Ice_cream "Ice
cream") in a [Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands "Netherlands") camel farm.[116]

#### Meat[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Camel&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Meat")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Somalicamelmeat.jpg/220px-
Somalicamelmeat.jpg)](/wiki/File:Somalicamelmeat.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Somalicamelmeat.jpg "Enlarge")

A [Somali](/wiki/Somali_people "Somali people") camel meat and rice dish.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Cholistani_Camel_Meat_Pulao.JPG/220px-
Cholistani_Camel_Meat_Pulao.JPG)](/wiki/File:Cholistani_Camel_Meat_Pulao.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Cholistani_Camel_Meat_Pulao.JPG "Enlarge")

Camel meat [pulao](/wiki/Pilaf "Pilaf"), from Pakistan.

Camels are the ultimate pillars that support national economies of many
developing countries, because they are useful for transport, and provide food
in the form of meat and milk (Tariq _et al._ ,2010).[117] A camel
[carcass](/wiki/Cadaver "Cadaver") can provide a substantial amount of meat.
The male dromedary carcass can weigh 300–400 kg (661–882 lb), while the
carcass of a male Bactrian can weigh up to 650 kg (1,433 lb). The carcass of a
female dromedary weighs less than the male, ranging between 250 and 350 kg
(550 and 770 lb).[15] The brisket, ribs and loin are among the preferred
parts, and the hump is considered a delicacy.[118] The hump contains "white
and sickly fat", which can be used to make the _khli_ (preserved meat) of
mutton, beef, or camel.[119] On the other hand, camel milk and meat are rich
in protein, vitamins, glycogen, and other nutrients making them essential in
the diet of many people. From chemical composition to meat quality, the
dromedary camel is the preferred breed for meat production. It does well even
in arid areas due to its unusual physiological behaviors and characteristics,
which include tolerance to extreme temperatures, radiation from the sun, water
paucity, rugged landscape and low vegetation (Aleme, 2013).[120] Camel meat is
reported to taste like coarse beef, but older camels can prove to be very
tough,[10][15] although camel meat becomes more tender the more it is
cooked.[121] The [Abu Dhabi](/wiki/Abu_Dhabi "Abu Dhabi") Officers' Club
serves a camel burger mixed with beef or lamb fat in order to improve the
texture and taste.[122] In [Karachi, Pakistan](/wiki/Karachi,_Pakistan
"Karachi, Pakistan"), some restaurants prepare [nihari](/wiki/Nihari "Nihari")
from camel meat.[123] In [Syria](/wiki/Syria "Syria") and [Egypt](/wiki/Egypt
"Egypt"), there are specialist camel butchers.[124]

Camel meat has been eaten for centuries. It has been recorded by [ancient
Greek](/wiki/Ancient_Greece "Ancient Greece") writers as an available dish at
banquets in ancient [Persia](/wiki/Persia "Persia"), usually roasted
whole.[125] The ancient [Roman](/wiki/Ancient_Rome "Ancient Rome") emperor
[Heliogabalus](/wiki/Elagabalus "Elagabalus") enjoyed camel's heel.[37] Camel
meat is still eaten in certain regions, including [Eritrea](/wiki/Eritrea
"Eritrea"), [Somalia](/wiki/Somalia "Somalia"), [Djibouti](/wiki/Djibouti
"Djibouti"), [Saudi Arabia](/wiki/Saudi_Arabia "Saudi Arabia"),
[Egypt](/wiki/Egypt "Egypt"), [Syria](/wiki/Syria "Syria"),
[Libya](/wiki/Libya "Libya"), [Sudan](/wiki/Sudan "Sudan"),
[Ethiopia](/wiki/Ethiopia "Ethiopia"), [Kazakhstan](/wiki/Kazakhstan
"Kazakhstan"), and other arid regions where alternative forms of protein may
be limited or where camel meat has had a long cultural history.[15][37][118]
Camel blood is also consumable, as is the case among pastoralists in northern
[Kenya](/wiki/Kenya "Kenya"), where camel blood is drunk with milk and acts as
a key source of [iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron"), [vitamin D](/wiki/Vitamin_D
"Vitamin D"), salts and minerals.[15][118][126] Camel meat is also
occasionally found in [Australian cuisine](/wiki/Australian_cuisine
"Australian cuisine"): for example, a camel [lasagna](/wiki/Lasagna "Lasagna")
is available in [Alice Springs](/wiki/Alice_Springs "Alice
Springs").[125][126]

A 2005 report issued jointly by the Saudi [Ministry of
Health](/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_\(Saudi_Arabia\) "Ministry of Health \(Saudi
Arabia\)") and the United States [Centers for Disease Control and
Prevention](/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention "Centers for
Disease Control and Prevention") details cases of human [bubonic
plague](/wiki/Bubonic_plague "Bubonic plague") resulting from the ingestion of
raw camel liver.[127]

### Religion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Camel&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Religion")]

#### Islam[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Camel&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: Islam")]

Camel meat is _[halal](/wiki/Halal "Halal")_ ([Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language
"Arabic language"): حَـلَال‎, 'allowed') for [Muslims](/wiki/Islam "Islam").
However, according to some [Islamic schools of
thought](/wiki/Islamic_schools_and_branches "Islamic schools and branches"), a
state of impurity is brought on by the consumption of it. Consequently, these
schools hold that Muslims must perform _[wudhu](/wiki/Wudhu "Wudhu")_
(ablution) before the next time they [pray](/wiki/Salat "Salat") after eating
camel meat.[128] Also, some Islamic schools of thought consider it
_[haram](/wiki/Haram "Haram")_ ([Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic
language"): حَـرَام‎, 'forbidden') for a Muslim to perform
_[Salat](/wiki/Salat "Salat")_ in places where camels lie, as it is said to be
a dwelling place of the _[Shaytan](/wiki/Devil_\(Islam\) "Devil \(Islam\)")_
([Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic language"): شَـيْـطَـان‎,
'[Devil](/wiki/Devil "Devil")').[128] According to [Abu Yusuf](/wiki/Abu_Yusuf
"Abu Yusuf"), the urine of camel may be used for medical treatment if
necessary, but according to [Abū Ḥanīfah](/wiki/Ab%C5%AB_%E1%B8%A4an%C4%ABfa
"Abū Ḥanīfa"), the drinking of camel urine is discouraged.[129]

The Islamic texts contain several stories featuring camels. In the story of
the people of [Thamud](/wiki/Thamud "Thamud"), the Prophet [Salih](/wiki/Salih
"Salih") miraculously brings forth a _[naqat](/wiki/She-Camel_of_God "She-
Camel of God")_ ([Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic language"): نَـاقَـة‎,
'she-camel') out of a rock. After the Prophet [Muhammad](/wiki/Muhammad
"Muhammad") [migrated](/wiki/Hegira "Hegira") from [Mecca](/wiki/Mecca
"Mecca") to [Medina](/wiki/Medina "Medina"), he allowed [his she-
camel](/wiki/Qaswa "Qaswa") to roam there; the location where the camel
stopped to rest determined the location where he would build his house in
Medina.[130]

#### Judaism[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Camel&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Judaism")]

See also: [Food and drink prohibitions](/wiki/Food_and_drink_prohibitions
"Food and drink prohibitions")

According to [Jewish](/wiki/Jewish "Jewish") tradition, camel meat and milk
are not [kosher](/wiki/Kosher "Kosher").[131] Camels possess only one of the
two [kosher criteria](/wiki/Kosher_foods "Kosher foods"); although they [chew
their cud](/wiki/Ruminant "Ruminant"), they do not possess [cloven
hooves](/wiki/Cloven_hoof "Cloven hoof"):

"But these you shall not eat among those that bring up the cud and those that
have a cloven hoof: the camel, because it brings up its cud, but does not have
a [completely] cloven hoof; it is unclean for you."[132]

## Distribution and
numbers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Camel&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section:
Distribution and numbers")]

[![A view into a canyon: many camels gathering around a watering
hole](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/GueltaCamels.jpg/270px-
GueltaCamels.jpg)](/wiki/File:GueltaCamels.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:GueltaCamels.jpg "Enlarge")

Camels in the [Guelta d'Archei](/wiki/Guelta_d%27Archei "Guelta d'Archei"), in
northeastern [Chad](/wiki/Chad "Chad")

There are around 14 million camels alive as of
2010[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Camel&action=edit), with
90% being dromedaries.[133] Dromedaries alive today are [domesticated
animals](/wiki/List_of_domesticated_animals "List of domesticated animals")
(mostly living in the [Horn of Africa](/wiki/Horn_of_Africa "Horn of Africa"),
the [Sahel](/wiki/Sahel "Sahel"), [Maghreb](/wiki/Maghreb "Maghreb"), [Middle
East](/wiki/Middle_East "Middle East") and [South Asia](/wiki/South_Asia
"South Asia")). The Horn region alone has the largest concentration of camels
in the world,[21] where the dromedaries constitute an [important part of local
nomadic life](/wiki/Nomadic_pastoralism "Nomadic pastoralism"). They provide
nomadic people in Somalia (which has the largest camel herd in the world)[15]
and Ethiopia with milk, food, and transportation.[108][134][135][136]

[![A world map with large camel populations
marked](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/800px-2003camel.PNG/300px-800px-2003camel.PNG)](/wiki/File:800px-2003camel.PNG)

[](/wiki/File:800px-2003camel.PNG "Enlarge")

Commercial camel market headcount in 2003

Around 700,000 dromedary camels are now [feral in
Australia](/wiki/Australian_feral_camel "Australian feral camel"), descended
from those introduced as a method of transport in the 19th and early 20th
centuries.[126][133][137] This population is growing about 8% per year.[138]
Representatives of the Australian government have culled more than 100,000 of
the animals in part because the camels use too much of the limited resources
needed by sheep farmers.[139]

A small population of introduced camels, dromedaries and Bactrians, wandered
through [Southwestern United States](/wiki/Southwestern_United_States
"Southwestern United States") after having been imported in the 19th century
as part of the [U.S. Camel Corps](/wiki/U.S._Camel_Corps "U.S. Camel Corps")
experiment. When the project ended, they were used as draft animals in mines
and escaped or were released. Twenty-five U.S. camels were bought and imported
to Canada during the [Cariboo Gold Rush](/wiki/Cariboo_Gold_Rush "Cariboo Gold
Rush").[89]

The Bactrian camel is, as of
2010[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Camel&action=edit),
reduced to an estimated 1.4 million animals, most of which are
domesticated.[40][133][140] The [Wild Bactrian
camel](/wiki/Wild_Bactrian_camel "Wild Bactrian camel") is a separate species
and is the only truly wild (as opposed to feral) camel in the world. The wild
camels are critically endangered and number approximately 1400, inhabiting the
Gobi and Taklamakan Deserts in China and Mongolia.[9][141]
